domain: Clinical Assessment, Professional Practice & Evidence-Based Treatment

questions.stem: A psychologist receives a subpoena from an attorney requesting complete copies of the WISC-V record form, stimulus booklet, and administration manual used during an evaluation of a child involved in a custody dispute. According to APA ethical standards, the psychologist should FIRST:

options.text: Comply immediately with the subpoena since it constitutes a legal demand
Refuse to release any information and invoke psychologist-client privilege
Contact the attorney to discuss the distinction between test data and test materials and attempt to protect test security
Release the record form but redact all test questions from the protocol

questions.explanation: Under Standards 9.04 and 9.11, psychologists distinguish between test data (scores, client responses, notes) and test materials (manuals, stimulus items, protocols). Test materials are protected for test security purposes. When faced with legal demands for test materials, the psychologist should first attempt to educate the requesting party about test security concerns and negotiate alternatives (e.g., in camera review, limiting access to qualified professionals). Simply complying without attempting to protect test security would violate Standard 9.11, while outright refusal may not be legally defensible.

questions.stem: Research on predictive bias in standardized cognitive tests has generally found that when a common regression equation is used to predict academic performance across racial groups, these tests tend to:

options.text: Underpredict performance for minority group members
Overpredict performance for minority group members
Accurately predict performance equally across all groups
Show different regression slopes but identical intercepts across groups

questions.explanation: Research on predictive bias using Cleary's model (qualified individualism) has consistently shown that standardized cognitive tests slightly overpredict the academic performance of minority groups. This means that predicted criterion scores are higher than actual performance for minority examinees when using a common regression equation. This overprediction finding is counterintuitive but well-established. It means test bias against minorities cannot explain lower criterion performance -- the tests are actually 'generous' in their predictions. This is a frequently tested concept on the EPPP.

questions.stem: According to APA Standard 9.03, informed consent for assessment is NOT required when:

options.text: The client is an adolescent who has been referred by their school
The evaluation is court-ordered and mandated by law
The psychologist is conducting a forensic evaluation for an insurance company
The client has a diagnosed intellectual disability

questions.explanation: Standard 9.03 specifies three exceptions to informed consent in assessment: (1) testing mandated by law or governmental regulation, (2) informed consent is implied because testing is a routine educational, institutional, or organizational activity, and (3) the purpose of testing is to evaluate decisional capacity. Court-ordered evaluations fall under the first exception. Even when consent is not required, the psychologist must still provide notification about the nature and purpose of the evaluation and the limits of confidentiality.

questions.stem: A psychologist is asked to provide an expert opinion on the psychological functioning of a plaintiff in a personal injury case. The plaintiff refuses to be evaluated. Under Standard 9.01, the psychologist may provide an opinion based on record review ONLY if the psychologist:

options.text: Has reviewed at least three independent sources of collateral information
Documents the efforts made to obtain a personal examination and clarifies the impact of limited information on reliability and validity of the opinion
Obtains written consent from the referring attorney to proceed without examination
Has conducted a similar evaluation on the plaintiff within the past five years

questions.explanation: Standard 9.01 (Bases for Assessments) states that when a personal examination is not practical, psychologists must document their efforts to obtain one, note the impact that limited information has on the reliability and validity of their opinions, and appropriately limit their conclusions. There is no requirement for a minimum number of collateral sources, attorney consent, or prior evaluation. The key obligation is transparency about the limitations of an opinion rendered without direct examination.

questions.stem: The four-fifths (4/5) rule, used as a screening guideline for adverse impact in employment testing, is satisfied when:

options.text: At least 80% of minority applicants pass the selection test
The selection rate for the minority group is at least 80% of the selection rate for the majority group
The test scores of minority applicants fall within 80% of the majority group mean
The reliability coefficient of the test is at least .80 for all groups

questions.explanation: The four-fifths (80%) rule is a guideline from the EEOC's Uniform Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures (1978). Adverse impact may be indicated when the selection rate for a protected group is less than four-fifths (80%) of the rate for the group with the highest selection rate. For example, if 60% of majority applicants are selected and only 40% of minority applicants are selected, the ratio is 40/60 = 0.67, which is below 0.80 and suggests adverse impact. The rule applies to selection rates, not raw scores or reliability coefficients.

questions.stem: A psychologist conducting a forensic competency evaluation must adhere to several ethical requirements that differ from clinical assessment. Which of the following are consistent with the Specialty Guidelines for Forensic Psychology (SGFP)? (Select ALL that apply.)

options.text: The psychologist's primary obligation is to the referral source, not the examinee
The psychologist must provide the examinee with a copy of the evaluation report before sharing it with the attorney
The forensic role must be clearly distinguished from any prior or concurrent therapeutic role
Reports should present findings in a balanced manner, including data that do not support the retaining party's position
The psychologist must inform the examinee about the nature and purpose of the evaluation and the limits of confidentiality

questions.explanation: The SGFP (2013) establish key principles: the forensic psychologist's primary obligation is to the retaining party; the forensic role must be distinguished from the therapeutic role; forensic reports should present balanced findings including data contradicting the retaining party's position; and even in mandated evaluations, the psychologist must inform the examinee about the nature, purpose, and limits of confidentiality. There is no requirement to share the report with the examinee before the retaining party.

questions.stem: When conducting a psychological evaluation of a recently immigrated non-English-speaking adult, which of the following practices are ethically required under APA standards? (Select ALL that apply.)

options.text: Considering the appropriateness of available norms for the individual's demographic and cultural group
Documenting the impact of language barriers and interpreter use on the validity of test results
Using only nonverbal tests to avoid any language-related measurement error
Assessing the individual's acculturation level to determine the applicability of normative data
Administering tests validated in the individual's native language when available

questions.explanation: Ethical cross-cultural assessment requires: evaluating norm appropriateness (Standard 9.06); documenting the impact of linguistic factors including interpreter use (Standard 9.02); assessing acculturation level to determine whether mainstream norms apply; and using natively validated tests when available. Exclusively using nonverbal tests would omit important verbal cognitive domains and provide an incomplete assessment. The goal is comprehensive evaluation accounting for cultural and linguistic factors, not avoidance of verbal measures.

questions.stem: Under APA ethical standards, which of the following constitute 'test data' that must generally be released upon valid client request? (Select ALL that apply.)

options.text: The client's raw scores on each subtest of the WAIS-IV
The psychologist's notes about the client's behavior during testing
The WAIS-IV administration manual and stimulus booklet
The client's verbatim responses to individual test items
Scaled score profiles and interpretive summary tables

questions.explanation: Standard 9.04 defines test data as raw and scaled scores, client responses, and psychologist's notes about client behavior during examination. This includes raw subtest scores, behavioral observations, verbatim item responses, and scaled score profiles. Test data must generally be released upon valid request unless substantial harm is anticipated. The WAIS-IV manual and stimulus booklet are test materials (Standard 9.11), protected for test security and NOT required to be released to clients.

questions.stem: The Multicultural Assessment-Intervention Process (MAIP) framework by Dana includes which of the following components? (Select ALL that apply.)

options.text: Determining the cultural orientation of the client
Incorporating emic versus etic perspectives in interpretation
Using culture-specific service delivery styles
Requiring translated versions of all tests administered
Selecting culturally appropriate instruments and norms

questions.explanation: Dana's MAIP framework includes four components: determining the cultural orientation of the client, selecting culturally appropriate instruments and norms, using culture-specific service delivery styles, and incorporating emic (culture-specific) versus etic (universal) perspectives. The MAIP does not require translated versions of all tests. While using validated translations is best practice when available, MAIP focuses on a broader conceptual approach rather than mandating specific procedural requirements.

questions.stem: Which of the following statements about measurement invariance are correct? (Select ALL that apply.)

options.text: Configural invariance means the same factor structure holds across groups
Scalar invariance is required for meaningful comparisons of group means
Metric invariance indicates that factor loadings are equal across groups
Strict invariance means residual variances are equal across groups
Configural invariance is sufficient for making meaningful group comparisons on observed score means

questions.explanation: Measurement invariance has increasingly restrictive levels: configural (same factor structure), metric (equal factor loadings), scalar (equal item intercepts), and strict (equal residual variances). Configural invariance alone only establishes that the same constructs are measured -- it does NOT ensure observed score means can be meaningfully compared. Scalar invariance (equal intercepts) is the minimum required for meaningful comparison of group means on latent constructs.

questions.stem: Match each legal case or regulation with its primary impact on psychological testing practices.
columns: Established job-relatedness requirement for employment tests
Banned IQ tests for EMR placement of Black children in California
Required testing accommodations for documented disabilities
Selection rate screening guideline for adverse impact

correctAnswers.Griggs v. Duke Power (1971): Established job-relatedness requirement for employment tests
correctAnswers.Larry P. v. Riles (1979): Banned IQ tests for EMR placement of Black children in California
correctAnswers.ADA (1990): Required testing accommodations for documented disabilities
correctAnswers.Four-Fifths Rule (EEOC): Selection rate screening guideline for adverse impact

questions.explanation: Griggs v. Duke Power (1971) established that employment tests must be job-related and consistent with business necessity, prohibiting tests with disparate impact without demonstrated validity. Larry P. v. Riles (1979) banned IQ tests for placing Black children into EMR classes in California, finding cultural bias and overrepresentation. The ADA (1990) requires reasonable testing accommodations for documented disabilities. The four-fifths rule is an EEOC guideline indicating adverse impact when the minority selection rate is less than 80% of the majority rate.

questions.stem: Match each APA Ethics Code standard with its primary requirement.
columns: Bases for assessments must be sufficient to substantiate findings
Release of test data to client upon valid request
Do not use obsolete tests or outdated results
Maintain test security and protect test materials

correctAnswers.Standard 9.01: Bases for assessments must be sufficient to substantiate findings
correctAnswers.Standard 9.04: Release of test data to client upon valid request
correctAnswers.Standard 9.08: Do not use obsolete tests or outdated results
correctAnswers.Standard 9.11: Maintain test security and protect test materials

questions.explanation: Standard 9.01 requires psychologists to base opinions on sufficient information. Standard 9.04 requires release of test data (scores, responses, notes) upon valid request unless substantial harm is anticipated. Standard 9.08 prohibits basing decisions on outdated data or obsolete instruments. Standard 9.11 requires protecting test materials, items, and protocols from unauthorized disclosure.

questions.stem: For each type of test bias, indicate which detection method(s) are appropriate. Select all that apply in each row.
questions.explanation: Item bias (DIF) is detected by comparing item performance across groups at equal ability levels using the Mantel-Haenszel statistic and IRT-based methods. Predictive bias (differential prediction) is detected through moderated regression analysis, testing whether regression equations differ across groups. Construct bias is detected through confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) and measurement invariance testing, examining whether the same latent constructs are measured across groups.

questions.stem: For each assessment scenario, indicate which ethical standards or guidelines are most directly relevant. Select all that apply in each row.
rows: Evaluating a non-English-speaking immigrant using an interpreter
Providing a computerized MMPI-3 narrative report directly to a patient
questions.explanation: Evaluating with an interpreter implicates Standard 9.02 (validity for population/purpose; interpreter may compromise standardization) and Standard 9.06 (consider linguistic and cultural factors in interpretation). Providing a computerized report directly to a patient implicates Standard 9.09 (psychologist retains responsibility for automated interpretation; reports should not be given to clients without professional review). Court-ordered competency evaluation implicates Standard 9.02 (valid instruments for forensic purpose) and the SGFP (mandated evaluations, role clarification, notification of purpose).

questions.stem:
Complete the following passage about test fairness models.
Cleary's definition of test fairness, also known as [BLANK1], states that a test is fair when the [BLANK2] relating test scores to criterion performance are equivalent across groups. This model focuses on whether the test shows [BLANK3]. In contrast, the equal probability model requires that examinees with equal probability of success on the criterion have equal probability of being [BLANK4] regardless of group membership.
questions.explanation: Cleary's model is 'qualified individualism' (vs. 'unqualified individualism' which uses the same cutoff for all groups). It defines a test as fair if the regression equations predicting criterion performance are equivalent across groups. When they differ, the test shows differential prediction (predictive bias). The equal probability model requires examinees with equal criterion success probability have equal probability of being selected. These models are not always compatible, which is a key EPPP concept.

questions.stem:
Complete the following passage about assessment of minors.
When conducting a psychological evaluation of a child, informed consent is obtained from the [BLANK1], while [BLANK2] is obtained from the child. The distinction is that [BLANK3] involves the child's agreement to participate with an age-appropriate understanding. When assessment results may be shared with [BLANK4], the limits of confidentiality must be clearly explained during the consent process.

options: the child's primary care physician only
no one outside the evaluating psychologist

questions.explanation: When assessing minors, informed consent is obtained from the parent or legal guardian. Assent is obtained from the child -- meaning the child agrees to participate with age-appropriate understanding. Assent differs from informed consent because children may lack full cognitive capacity to understand all aspects of the evaluation, but their willingness to participate is ethically important. Results may be shared with schools, courts, and other agencies depending on the evaluation purpose, and these limits must be discussed during the consent process.

questions.stem: A psychologist uses the WAIS-III (published 1997) to evaluate a 25-year-old adult for possible intellectual disability in 2024, despite the WAIS-IV (2008) being readily available.
questions.explanation: The Flynn effect describes IQ scores increasing approximately 3 points per decade. WAIS-III norms from 1997 (27 years old) inflate scores by approximately 8 points. A person scoring in the intellectual disability range on current norms could score above the threshold on outdated norms, resulting in a missed diagnosis. Standard 9.08 prohibits basing decisions on obsolete instruments when newer versions are available. Artificially inflated scores could prevent an individual from receiving necessary services.

options.text: The psychologist is more familiar with WAIS-III administration procedures
The WAIS-III norms are outdated and inflated by the Flynn effect
The client specifically requested the older version of the test
The WAIS-III was validated on a more diverse normative sample
The client's scores will appear artificially lower, leading to overdiagnosis
The client's scores will appear artificially higher, potentially missing a valid diagnosis of intellectual disability
The subtest structure will be invalid for the client's age group
The test results will show artificially elevated processing speed scores

questions.centerStatement: Violation of Standard 9.08 (Obsolete Tests and Outdated Results)

questions.stem: A psychologist who has been treating a client for depression for 18 months is asked by the client's attorney to conduct a forensic evaluation of the same client for a personal injury lawsuit.
questions.explanation: The SGFP (2013) caution against combining therapeutic and forensic roles. The therapeutic relationship creates advocacy bias, while forensic work requires objectivity. A treating clinician cannot provide an unbiased forensic opinion about a current client. The recommended action is to decline the forensic role and refer to an independent evaluator. Disclosing the dual role does not eliminate bias. Terminating therapy to begin forensic work is problematic as it abandons the therapeutic relationship without removing pre-existing bias.

options.text: The psychologist has a pre-existing therapeutic relationship that could bias forensic objectivity
The psychologist lacks the required forensic training credentials
The client's attorney did not provide adequate documentation of the injury
The psychologist's malpractice insurance does not cover forensic work
Conduct the forensic evaluation but disclose the therapeutic relationship in the report
Decline the forensic evaluation role and refer to an independent forensic evaluator
Terminate therapy before beginning the forensic evaluation
Obtain a waiver from the client acknowledging the dual role

questions.centerStatement: Dual role conflict between therapist and forensic evaluator as prohibited by the SGFP

questions.stem: Review the following assessment ethics scenario. Highlight ALL statements that represent ethical violations.
questions.passage: A psychologist receives a referral to evaluate a 10-year-old bilingual (Spanish-English) child for possible learning disability. The psychologist administers the WISC-V in English without assessing the child's language dominance. The psychologist obtains informed consent from the child's mother, who speaks limited English, by having the child translate the consent form. The psychologist also obtains verbal assent from the child before beginning testing. During testing, the psychologist notes that the child appears fatigued and anxious. The psychologist continues administering all subtests without any breaks to maintain standardization. After completing the evaluation, the psychologist sends the written report directly to the school without explaining the results to the parent. The psychologist stores all test protocols and raw data in a locked filing cabinet in the office.
correctHighlights: The psychologist administers the WISC-V in English without assessing the child's language dominance.
The psychologist continues administering all subtests without any breaks to maintain standardization.
After completing the evaluation, the psychologist sends the written report directly to the school without explaining the results to the parent.
questions.explanation: Three ethical violations: (1) Administering the WISC-V without assessing language dominance violates Standards 9.02 and 9.06, as the test may measure English proficiency rather than cognitive ability. (2) Continuing without breaks when a child shows fatigue and anxiety violates Standard 9.02 -- rigid standardization at the expense of valid results is not defensible, and most manuals allow breaks. (3) Sending the report without explaining results to the parent violates Standard 9.10, requiring reasonable steps to explain results. Obtaining assent from the child is appropriate and NOT a violation.

questions.stem: Review the following passage about test security and data release. Highlight ALL statements that are INCORRECT according to APA ethical standards.
questions.passage: Test data includes raw scores, scaled scores, and the psychologist's notes about client behavior during testing. Test materials include the test manual, stimulus items, and the client's answer sheet. When a client requests their test data, the psychologist must release it unless substantial harm or misuse is anticipated. When a court orders release of test materials, the psychologist should refuse outright to comply with the order to protect test security. Psychologists may release copyrighted test items directly to clients as long as the client signs a nondisclosure agreement.
correctHighlights: Test materials include the test manual, stimulus items, and the client's answer sheet.
When a court orders release of test materials, the psychologist should refuse outright to comply with the order to protect test security.
Psychologists may release copyrighted test items directly to clients as long as the client signs a nondisclosure agreement.
questions.explanation: Statement about test data definition is CORRECT. The test materials statement is INCORRECT -- the client's answer sheet (containing actual responses) is test DATA, not test materials. The court order statement is INCORRECT -- outright refusal may be contempt of court; instead, make reasonable efforts to protect test security (in camera review, limit access to qualified professionals). The nondisclosure statement is INCORRECT -- copyrighted test items are protected under Standard 9.11 and copyright law; a nondisclosure agreement does not authorize release to unqualified individuals.

questions.stem: Arrange the levels of measurement invariance in the correct hierarchical order, from least restrictive to most restrictive.

items.text: Strict invariance (equal residual variances)
Configural invariance (same factor structure)
Scalar invariance (equal intercepts)
Metric invariance (equal factor loadings)

questions.explanation: Measurement invariance is tested through increasingly restrictive levels: (1) Configural -- same factor structure across groups. (2) Metric -- equal factor loadings, meaning scale units are equivalent. (3) Scalar -- equal item intercepts, necessary for meaningful comparison of group means. (4) Strict -- equal residual variances. Each level is nested within the next. Researchers test sequentially, stopping when a model shows significant misfit.

questions.stem: Arrange the following steps in the correct ethical sequence for conducting a forensic psychological evaluation.

items.text: Obtain and review all relevant records and collateral information
Clarify the referral question and the psychologist's role with the retaining party
Administer assessment instruments selected for their relevance and validity for the forensic question
Inform the examinee about the nature, purpose, and limits of confidentiality of the evaluation
Prepare a balanced written report and communicate findings to the retaining party

questions.explanation: Ethical forensic evaluation sequence: (1) Clarify referral question and role with retaining party. (2) Obtain and review all relevant records for context. (3) Inform the examinee about nature, purpose, and limits of confidentiality (notification required even in mandated evaluations). (4) Administer instruments selected for forensic relevance and validity. (5) Prepare a balanced report including findings that may not support the retaining party's position.

questions.stem: A selection test is used in hiring for a large corporation. The following data show the selection rates for majority and minority applicants over five years. Based on the four-fifths rule, identify the CORRECT interpretation of when adverse impact was present.
options: Adverse impact was present in all five years because minority selection rates were consistently lower than majority rates
Adverse impact was present in Years 2, 3, and 4 (ratios below 0.80), but not in Years 1 and 5 (ratios at or above 0.80)
No adverse impact was present because the average ratio across all five years exceeds 0.80
Adverse impact was present only in Year 4 because it had the lowest absolute minority selection rate
questions.explanation: The four-fifths rule: adverse impact exists when the minority/majority selection rate ratio is below 0.80. Year 1 = 0.84 (no), Year 2 = 0.73 (yes), Year 3 = 0.73 (yes), Year 4 = 0.75 (yes), Year 5 = 0.83 (no). The rule applies to ratios, not absolute rates. Adverse impact is not determined by averaging across years or looking at the lowest absolute rate. Each year's ratio is evaluated independently against the 0.80 threshold.

questions.stem: A psychologist examines IQ scores of a normative sample tested on the same instrument at different time points to assess the Flynn effect. All scores use the original 1980 norms. A client scores 73 using the 1980 norms in a 2020 evaluation. What is the BEST interpretation?
options: The client's score of 73 accurately reflects their intellectual functioning relative to the current population
Using the 1980 norms in 2020 inflates the client's score by approximately 11-12 points, so their true score relative to current peers is likely around 61-62
The Flynn effect only applies to fluid intelligence measures, so this analysis is irrelevant for the WAIS
The client's estimated true score relative to current norms is approximately 73, adjusted downward by the Flynn effect, placing them further below the disability threshold
questions.explanation: The Flynn effect shows IQ increasing approximately 3 points per decade. From 1980 to 2020, the 40-year span produces approximately 11.5 points of norm inflation. The client's score of 73 on 1980 norms would be approximately 61.5 on 2020 norms, well within the intellectual disability range. Outdated norms made the score appear higher, which could cause a missed diagnosis. This demonstrates why Standard 9.08 prohibits use of obsolete tests. Option D incorrectly describes the adjustment direction.

questions.stem: Categorize each of the following as either 'Test Data' (releasable upon client request under Standard 9.04) or 'Test Materials' (protected under Standard 9.11).

items.text: Client's raw subtest scores on the WAIS-IV
The WAIS-IV administration manual
Psychologist's notes about client behavior during testing
Rorschach inkblot stimulus cards
Client's verbatim responses to TAT cards
MMPI-3 test booklet with copyrighted items
Scaled score profile and composite score summary
Scoring algorithms and interpretive keys

questions.explanation: Test data (Standard 9.04): raw/scaled scores, client responses, psychologist's behavioral notes -- releasable upon valid request. Test materials (Standard 9.11): manuals, stimulus materials, test booklets, scoring algorithms -- protected for test security. Key distinction: test data reflects the CLIENT's individual performance, while test materials are the INSTRUMENTS themselves belonging to the test publisher.

questions.stem: Categorize each assessment scenario as representing a situation where informed consent IS required or where informed consent is NOT required (but notification of purpose is still necessary).

items.text: A psychologist conducts a private-practice cognitive evaluation at a parent's request
A court-ordered forensic competency evaluation of a criminal defendant
An employer-mandated fitness-for-duty evaluation of a police officer
A psychologist evaluates a therapy client's suitability for a new treatment modality
Routine standardized achievement testing administered to all students in a school district
A neuropsychological evaluation requested by a client's personal injury attorney

questions.explanation: Standard 9.03 exceptions: (1) testing mandated by law (court-ordered, employer-mandated), (2) routine institutional activity (school-wide testing), (3) evaluating decisional capacity. Even in these exceptions, notification of purpose is required. Full consent IS required for: voluntary clinical evaluations, treatment planning assessments, and evaluations requested by the client's own attorney. The key distinction is mandatory/institutional (notification only) vs. voluntary/client-initiated (full consent).
